story.storybody:
Grappling with perennial congestion and inadequate crowd management, the New Delhi railway station may soon get a French treatment. The French railways may take up the much-needed redevelopment of the station. A high-power delegation of the French government and railway officials inspected the railway station on Thursday, which is bursting at the seams. Officials hinted that the existing station building can be raised into a high-rise, giving ample scope for commercial exploitation. The French Railway (SNCF) has already agreed to take up redevelopment of Ambala Cantonment and Ludhiana railway stations.

Problem areas

Congestion remains the major concern at the New Delhi station. The station operates close to 350 trains and witnesses a footfall of 5-6 lakhs regularly. This results in heavy rush on the platforms. The situation aggravates during the festive season and summers. This often leads to train misses and even stampede-like situations like the one in May 2010, when 2 people were killed in a stampede.

Constraints

Both entry/exit to the railway stations - Paharganj and Ajmeri Gate - are fully saturated, leaving no space for horizontal expansion of the railway station. Encroachment on the Paharganj side is to such an extent that visitors have to jostle to park their vehicles. The station also operates premium trains like the Rajdhani and Shatabdi Express, thereby hosting foreign tourists. With little availability of space, there are not enough executive lounges, waiting halls or cafeterias.

Solution

The railways is exploring options for vertical expansion of the station, aiming to develop it into a world class facility. The station may have separate terminals for arrival and departure like airports. Parts of it can be leased out to business entities for commercial purposes, including retail outlets, eating joints, a multiplex and private offices.
